@YangTerrence A lot of the best deals are privately syndicated - you have to be backing the syndicator to see them.
@rsg We are starting to do it. Top leads already have 10-deal funds forming on AL. Obvious next step.
@rsg @aten Can't assume Backers back one lead for many deals. Most Backers back many deals and many leads. They like to choose deal by deal.
@rsg @aten forcing fund would mean barrier to entry goes up 10x. And backers locked in. Skin in game and transparency are aligners
@semil @rsg And even known leads flop when pushing mediocre deals. The market is transparent and the backers choose.
@semil @rsg Backers can look at each deal and decide. For good companies with traction, unknown leads can get carry. Not otherwise.
@rsg the "2" is 2x10=20 off the top, only 80 invested.. Syndicate equivalent is 0 fee, 100 invested.
@rsg I was a VC and got away with zero skin in game + mgmt fees... It was a good deal ;-)
@rsg agreed. It's nuanced. We made one sub-optimal trade off for ~5 benefits. Backers seem to prefer it but not perfect.
@rsg Large VCs have management fees. Syndicates have none. Opposite - they have mandatory skin in the game. And all money gets put to work.
@rsg online. Happy to discuss offline. Twitter is not the right venue anyway.
@rsg we could move to net carry but that would mean Backers are locked into long haul, money up front across 4 yrs of deals. Wouldn't work
@rsg on raw percentage terms. So it's not perfect but better than status quo.
@rsg Lead deals are also 100% transparent. Add in no management fees, required skin in game, disclose conflicts. They also charge low carry
@rsg Syndicates are deal by deal. But flip side is that backers can evaluate individual deals and opt out. They can fire leads with 1 click.
